news.title: Kaindu Leaves DeMbare
news.content:
Sports Correspondent  Dynamos coach Kelvin Kaindu has officially announced his departure from the Harare giants, bringing an end to his stint with DeMbare after achieving key objectives with the club.

In a statement released on Monday following his move to Hardrock, Kaindu described the decision to leave Dynamos as a difficult one, saying the club had become a home to him during his time in charge.

It hasnt been an easy decision to make. Personally, I see Dynamos as my home, said Kaindu. The main objective set was to survive relegation, which we managed to achieve, and the Chibuku Super Cup victory was an icing on the cake.

Kaindu expressed gratitude to the clubs leadership and stakeholders, acknowledging the support he received throughout his tenure.

I would like to thank the Dynamos F.C owner, Mr B.M Lusengo, the Executive Committee, management, sponsors, and technical team for the working relationship we had, he said. Not forgetting the players who helped us survive relegation.

He emphasised that the achievements at the club were a result of collective effort rather than individual brilliance.

It will be even more difficult for me to single out individuals, but I attribute this to team effort and commitment, Kaindu noted.

The departing coach also thanked supporters and individuals who stood by him, admitting that the decision may have disappointed some fans.

I know I could have disappointed a lot of people, but this wasnt an easy decision for me to make, he said. This is a difficult moment for me knowing that Im not staying at Dynamos, but I believe that Ive created a working relationship that leaves the door open for the future.

Kaindu concluded his message by wishing Dynamos success in the upcoming season and beyond.

Thank you for the tremendous support. I wish DeMbare all the best for success this coming season and beyond.
news.description: Sports Correspondent – Dynamos coach Kelvin Kaindu has officially announced his departure from the Harare giants, bringing an end to …

news.title: ZRP Cop In Hot Soup For Sleeping With Schoolgirl
news.content:
By A Correspondent  A Bulawayo-based police officer is facing legal action after being accused of engaging in a sexual relationship with a 17year-old schoolgirl.

Mduduzi Dube, 32, who works at the Police Updating Centre (PUC) at Ross Camp, appeared before Magistrate Patience Madondo last Thursday, facing two counts under Section 70 of the Criminal Law (Codification and Reform) Act, which criminalises sexual activity with minors.

Prosecutor Joseph Rugara told the court that Dube allegedly took the Form 4 pupil from Njube High School to his uncles house in Sauerstown in August 2025, where the sexual activity is said to have occurred. A similar incident allegedly took place at the same location in October.

The National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) reported that the girl later disclosed the incidents, leading to a police investigation. She has undergone a medical examination, with the results expected to be used as evidence.

Court papers describe Dube as the complainants boyfriend, but the NPA emphasised that consent is not a factor in cases involving minors, as the law protects young people regardless of agreement.

Dubes lawyer, Takunda Chapisa, applied for bail, which was granted by the court.
news.description: By A Correspondent – A Bulawayo-based police officer is facing legal action after being accused of engaging in a sexual …

news.title: Mnangagwa Jersey Sparks Fears of Curse Ahead of AFCON
news.content:
Tinashe Sambiri President Emmerson Mnangagwa was presented with the new Warriors jersey by ZIFA president Nqobile Magwizi ahead of Zimbabwes Africa Cup of Nations campaign. While intended as a morale booster, critics argue the gesture raises more questions than answers.

The presentation followed President Mnangagwas release of US$400 000 to support the Warriors preparations, covering logistical and technical needs. Yet analysts warn that financial support and ceremonial photo ops do little to address the teams longstanding challenges.

Giving out jerseys and money does not fix the systemic issues that have haunted Zimbabwean football for years, said one sports analyst. The Warriors inconsistent performance cannot be solved with gestures alone.

Fans echoed these concerns, with some calling for improved training, coaching, and strategy instead of high-profile presentations. We need real investment in the team, not just a presidential showpiece, commented one supporter.

As the Warriors prepare to depart for Morocco, debate rages over whether the jersey is a blessing or a bad omen, with skeptics fearing the gesture could do more harm than good.
news.description: Tinashe Sambiri– President Emmerson Mnangagwa was presented with the new Warriors jersey by ZIFA president Nqobile Magwizi ahead of Zimbabwe’s …

news.title: Zanu PF Heavyweights Vow To Block Tungwarara Ascendancy
news.content:
Tinashe Sambiri Zanu PF heavyweights in Manicaland have vowed to block President Emmerson Mnangagwas advisor, Dr. Paul Tungwarara, from ascending to the partys Central Committee, despite provincial recommendations supporting his co-option.

A Zanu PF source revealed: At the weekend, the Manicaland Provincial Coordinating Committee (PCC) convened an inter-district meeting, where Chipinge District presented Dr. Tungwarara as their candidate for the vacant Central Committee post. Representatives from various districts attended, and after the presentations, Dr. Tungwararas name will be forwarded to the national leadership for consideration and adoption. In addition, Dr. P. Tungwarara disbursed the Presidential Constituency Empowerment Fund for all constituencies in Buhera District.

However, party hardliners in the province have expressed strong opposition to the move, signaling potential internal friction. One senior member, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: We will not allow personal interests or affiliations to dictate who sits on the Central Committee. Dr. Tungwararas co-option is not in the best interest of the province.

The standoff highlights ongoing tensions within Zanu PF, with factions appearing divided over loyalty, influence, and control at both provincial and national levels. The final decision on Dr. Tungwararas Central Committee position now rests with the national leadership, which will have to navigate these competing pressures.
news.description: Tinashe Sambiri– Zanu PF heavyweights in Manicaland have vowed to block President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s advisor, Dr. Paul Tungwarara, from ascending …

news.title: Civil Servants Demand Reality, Not Promises As Mthuli Ncube Announces Pay Increase
news.content:
Tinashe Sambiri Civil servants have reacted with skepticism after Finance, Economic Development and Investment Promotion Minister Mthuli Ncube announced a planned salary increase in the first quarter of next year, saying the promise does little to ease their daily struggles.

Speaking in the National Assembly during debate on the 2026 National Budget, Ncube said funds from the Unallocated Reserves had been set aside to facilitate the adjustment, while admitting the resources were limited.

I would really like to persuade our colleagues. We have a limited purse. I know Hon (Corban) Madzivanyika did mention that we seem to have a large Unallocated Reserve. I can assure you it is not large at all. It will go so fast and so quickly, Ncube said.

He added: One issue is the budget for salary adjustments for civil servants in the first quarter. It is going to happen, and it is based on the job evaluation exercise. It is going to eat away quite a lot of that Unallocated Reserve. It will not go far.

However, many civil servants say the announcement offers little comfort, citing years of eroded wages and rising living costs. We have heard these promises before, said one government worker. What matters is what actually ends up in our payslips, not what is said in Parliament.

With inflation and basic expenses continuing to rise, workers say they remain focused on the harsh economic reality, viewing Ncubes announcement as yet another pledge that may fail to translate into meaningful relief.

Mthuli Ncube
news.description: Tinashe Sambiri– Civil servants have reacted with skepticism after Finance, Economic Development and Investment Promotion Minister Mthuli Ncube announced a …

news.title: BREAKING NEWS: Mthuli Hikes Online Fees
news.content:
By Business Reporter-Zimbabweans are now paying more to use international digital platforms after banks quietly raised charges on foreign online transactions, following new government tax measures.

An SMS sent to bank customers Monday,  shows that, from5 January 2026, fees onVisa international POS and e-commerce transactionswill rise from1% to 2.2% per transaction, with additional charges for failed payments. This means every payment made to services such asChatGPT, Netflix, Starlink, Grammarly, Spotify, and e-hailing appswill now cost more.

The increase is linked to Treasurys decision to introduce a15% Digital Services Withholding Taxon payments to offshore digital platforms starting1 January 2026.

Most Zimbabweans pay for digital services in foreign currency, and the money goes straight outside the country. The government says this has been happening without proper taxation, giving foreign companies an advantage over local businesses and steadily eroding national revenue.

Banks and mobile money platforms will now deduct the tax automatically at the point of payment. Customers will not pay the tax directly, but it will be built into higher charges, as already reflected in bank alerts.

Ordinary users will feel the impact immediately through higher subscription costs, more expensive online payments, and extra charges even on declined transactions. While the State is moving fast to tax global digital platforms, local media houses, online publishers and content creators continue to struggle to earn a sustainable income online.

The key question is whether this new tax will level the playing field or further squeeze citizens already burdened by rising costs of living. One thing is clear: the digital economy is now being taxed  and ordinary Zimbabweans are paying first.
news.description: By Business Reporter-Zimbabweans are now paying more to use international digital platforms after banks quietly raised charges on foreign online …

news.title: Zisco Steel, The Institution That Died After Independence
news.content:
By Engineer Jacob Kudzayi Mutisi | The towering blast furnaces of the Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company (Zisco Steel) once symbolised the promise of an industrialised Zimbabwe. For years, Zisco was not merely a factory, it was a nation-builder. It supplied steel to railways, construction, agriculture, mining and manufacturing, while sustaining entire towns and generations of skilled workers. Yet, tragically, this industrial giant did not survive the era it was meant to empower. Zisco Steel did not die before independence, it died after it.

At independence in 1980, Zimbabwe inherited one of Africas most sophisticated integrated steel plants. Zisco had trained apprentices, technicians, artisans, engineers and metallurgists, it had captive iron ore, coke ovens, rolling mills and export markets. Few newly independent African states possessed such a strategic industrial asset. Properly managed, Zisco could have been the backbone of national reconstruction, infrastructure development and value-added exports for decades to come.

Instead, independence marked the beginning of a slow and painful decline. In the early years after independence, Zisco continued to operate and employ thousands. Redcliff and Kwekwe thrived as industrial towns, with decent housing, schools, clinics and stable incomes. Steel production underpinned roads, dams, factories and railways the very skeleton of the economy.

However, as the years progressed, political interference replaced professional management, long-term investment gave way to short-term survival and maintenance of critical equipment was deferred until failure became inevitable. Strategic decisions were often driven by patronage rather than competence. By the 1990s, inefficiencies had crept in, debts mounted, and reinvestment lagged behind global technological change.

Zisco became a victim of policy inconsistency, foreign currency shortages, power cuts and an inability to operate as a commercial entity in a competitive global steel market. What should have been modernised was cannibalised. What should have been protected as strategic national infrastructure was neglected.

By mid 2000s, production had virtually ceased. Thousands of workers were sent home without salaries, pensions or medical support. Families that had depended on Zisco for generations were plunged into poverty. Redcliff, once a model industrial town began to resemble a ghost settlement, marked by abandoned houses, shuttered businesses and broken hopes.

Former employees, some now elderly and unwell, waited years for pensions that never came. Many died in hardship, their skills and service discarded without dignity. The collapse of Zisco was not only an economic failure, it was a moral failure.

Over the years, multiple revival plans were announced with fanfare foreign investors, management contracts and public-private partnerships. Each promised a turnaround all delivered nothing. Assets deteriorated further, equipment was stripped or vandalised and confidence evaporated. The absence of transparency and accountability turned rescue efforts into exercises in delay rather than recovery.

While smaller private steel players emerged elsewhere, Zimbabwe lost what no small mill could replace, an integrated steel ecosystem capable of supporting heavy industry, railways, shipbuilding, defence manufacturing and large-scale infrastructure.

The death of Zisco Steel after independence is a painful lesson. Political freedom without economic discipline, institutional integrity and industrial strategy is incomplete. Nations are not built on slogans alone, they are built on functioning institutions, competent leadership and respect for technical expertise.

Zisco did not fail because Zimbabwe lacked resources. The country has iron ore, coal, skilled people and regional markets. Zisco failed because the institution was allowed to die.

As Zimbabwe speaks again of industrialisation, beneficiation and value addition, the rusting remains of Zisco stand as a warning. Reviving industry is not about announcements it is about governance, investment, skills and continuity. Until those lessons are learnt, Zisco Steel will remain what it is today, a fallen giant and a symbol of what Zimbabwe could have been and still could be if institutions are protected rather than sacrificed.

Engineer Jacob Kudzayi Mutisi+263772278161
news.description: By Engineer Jacob Kudzayi Mutisi | The towering blast furnaces of the Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company (Zisco Steel) once …

news.title: Zanu PF Heavyweights Seize Basic Education Assistance Programme
news.content:
Tinashe Sambiri- Government bureaucrats and Zanu PF heavyweights have taken control of the Basic Education Assistance Module (BEAM), it has emerged.

BEAM, designed to support vulnerable pupils in communities, is reportedly being manipulated by government officials to benefit those with influence, leaving the genuinely needy at a disadvantage. In response, the government has announced plans to conduct an audit to identify and expose those involved.

During last weeks debate on the Finance Bill for the proposed 2026 National Budget, Finance Minister Professor Mthuli Ncube said Cabinet had taken a firm position on the matter and that an audit would soon be carried out.

Now, turning to BEAM arrears and so forth, colleagues, in Bulawayo, when we debated this issue, I explained that the Government has taken a position through Cabinet that an audit should be undertaken, and because other concerns have come up, to say that a good part of these beneficiaries from BEAM are not deserving cases, Professor Ncube said.

What we are finding is that the system for identification of the vulnerable is being manipulated by those with influence and leverage in various areas. This needs to be audited so that we get to know who is really vulnerable, he added.

It looks like those who are in need are not benefiting. That is the information we have. Therefore, we do not want to rush in without doing this audit work.

Concerns have also been raised over the governments failure to disburse BEAM funds to schools. The Portfolio Committee on Primary and Secondary Education, chaired by Nyanga South MP Supa Mandiwanzira, noted that this delay was affecting school operations.

I am standing to support the proposal that has been made by my colleague Honourable Member that the line item about the Basic Education Assistance Module, in fact, be redirected to the Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education. Not only does it reduce transaction costs, but in the last three years, there have not been any disbursements to the schools on these Basic Education Assistance Module (BEAM) allocations. It would also ensure that there are actual disbursements going to schools for this purpose, Mandiwanzira said.

Zaka South MP Clemence Chiduwa also commented on the allocation, praising the increase but highlighting concerns over its release.

The allocation is showing an increase from ZWG2.4 billion to ZWG5.58 billion for the year 2026. This is an increase of more than 100%. However, what is critical is not just the allocation but the releases. The issue that we are having with the schools is that most schools are now going down because the majority of our students are under BEAM. I would want to urge the Hon. Minister to synchronise allocation and releases. The ZWG5.58 billion allocated is quite commendable, Chiduwa said.

Moreover, there is the issue of the BEAM Information Management System. You mentioned that there are quite several ghosts or undeserving pupils who are benefiting from BEAM. I think this is again a commendable move which should be deployed as soon as we start 2026.

Opposition MP Gladys Hlatywayo argued for allocating BEAM funds through the Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education rather than the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare.

This is because I think that allocating it to the Ministry of Public Service, Labour and Social Welfare would increase the transaction cost. So, we can reduce the transaction cost by just directing it to the Ministry that is dealing with the particular issue and, in particular, the Ministry of Education, she said.
news.description: Tinashe Sambiri- Government bureaucrats and Zanu PF heavyweights have taken control of the Basic Education Assistance Module (BEAM), it has …

news.title: The Rise of Polite Kambamura
news.content:
By A Correspondent-President Emmerson Mnangagwas twin sons, Sean and Collins, are behind the rise of Mines Minister Polite Kambamura, ZimEye has established.

Kambamura was appointed last Monday, hours after the abrupt dismissal of Winston Chitando, whose removal followed escalating disputes over mining interests linked to the Mnangagwa twins and rival interests associated with Vice President Constantino Chiwenga.

Chitando was fired while attending a strategic planning workshop for his ministry in Masvingo. Sources say he was informed of his dismissal while still on duty, a development that reportedly shocked both him and senior officials present. President Mnangagwa moved swiftly to replace him with his deputy, Polite Kambamura, with the reshuffle taking immediate effect.

In a brief statement, Chief Secretary to the President and Cabinet Dr Martin Rushwaya said Chitandos removal was effected in terms of Section 340, read together with Section 108 of the Constitution. No official reasons were given.

Behind the scenes, however, multiple sources within the Ministry of Mines say Chitandos exit was the culmination of prolonged tensions over the allocation of lucrative mining licences and concessions.

According to senior officials, Chitando had repeatedly resisted pressure to approve mining deals linked to Collins and Sean Mnangagwa. These allegedly included foreign-backed lithium ventures in Mashonaland Central, particularly around Mbire, as well as gold concessions in Mazowe.

The minister was under sustained pressure to sign off on deals brought to him by the Presidents sons, said one senior official. On several occasions they sought meetings with him, but he refused to give them an audience.

That resistance, sources say, proved costly.

Collins and Sean Mnangagwa have in recent years become increasingly influential within their fathers political and economic orbit. Senior party and government insiders allege that the twins often act as informal gatekeepers to the President, demanding large sums  reportedly up to US$50,000  from businesspeople seeking access to Mnangagwa for investment discussions. While such claims have never been tested in court, they are widely cited within political and business circles.

Major Sean Mnangagwa, who recently joined his fathers close security detail, has also emerged as a constant presence on both domestic and international trips, often alongside his twin brother. Sources allege that some of these trips have doubled as platforms for advancing private business interests under the cover of official government delegations.

Analysts describe this growing influence as part of a broader pattern of family-centred state capture, with the Mnangagwa network now linked to gold, chrome, lithium, fuel procurement and major infrastructure contracts.

Chitandos troubles were further compounded by friction with Vice President Chiwenga. Sources say the former minister clashed with the VP over the cancellation of gold mining permits allegedly held by individuals aligned to Chiwenga. Those permits were reportedly withdrawn and reassigned, triggering complaints that reached the highest levels of government.

This was not the first time Chitandos position had been undermined by elite disputes. ZimLive previously reported that he had once been removed from the mines portfolio after allegedly attempting to interfere in a mining claim linked to Chiwenga. Although he later returned to the ministry, insiders say the tensions never fully dissipated.

Chitando, a former managing director of Mimosa Mining Company, was first appointed Mines Minister in 2017 as part of Mnangagwas first post-Mugabe cabinet, initially billed as a technocratic team. He survived several reshuffles, was moved to Local Government in 2023, and then reappointed to Mines a year later. In recent months, however, he was increasingly viewed as politically vulnerable as factional battles within Zanu PF intensified and Mnangagwa tightened control over strategic ministries.

His successor, Polite Kambamura, a 48-year-old mining engineer from Sanyati, is widely regarded as a close associate of Collins and Sean Mnangagwa. Sources say his relationship with the twins dates back to the Mugabe era and is rooted in gold dealings around Sanyati, Kadoma and surrounding areas, where he allegedly wielded influence over artisanal miners.

President Mnangagwa did not even know Kambamura personally, a source claimed. He was introduced to him by his sons soon after the 2017 coup. The same applies to other younger ministers like Jenfan Muswere and Sithembiso Nyoni  they are all friends of the twins, and that is how they entered Cabinet.

Kambamuras appointment comes amid heightened public scrutiny of the Mines Ministry, long accused of corruption, opaque licensing processes and domination by politically connected cartels.

His own public profile is not without controversy. Australia-based activist Susan Mutami has previously alleged that Kambamura was her former lover and claimed he maintained relationships with several high-profile media personalities, including Samantha Musa (Miss Red) and broadcaster Rumbi Takawira. She described the women as part of what she termed a network of slay queens linked to powerful politicians and businessmen.

None of those named have publicly confirmed the allegations, and Kambamura has never formally responded. Government officials have dismissed the claims as private matters unrelated to public office. Nonetheless, the allegations circulated widely on social media, fuelling debates about patronage, power and gendered exploitation within Zimbabwes political elite.

Kambamura now assumes control of one of the countrys most politically and economically sensitive ministries, at a time when competition for control of Zimbabwes vast mineral wealth is intensifying.

Chitandos dismissal stands out as one of Mnangagwas most consequential cabinet moves in recent months, signalling a recalibration of power at the heart of the mining sector. Whether Kambamura will reform a ministry long viewed as a battleground for elite interests  or simply oversee a deeper consolidation of control by politically connected actors  remains an open question.
news.description: By A Correspondent-President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s twin sons, Sean and Collins, are behind the rise of Mines Minister Polite Kambamura, ZimEye …
